resamplr
  • Reference
  • Articles

Generate Jackknife Subsamples

Generate jackknife subsamples. For data with \(n\) elements, the jackknife generates \(n\) subsamples, each with one element deleted. The generalized (delete-\(p\), block) jackknife generates subsamples by deleting p observations.

jackknife(data, p, ...)

# S3 method for data.frame
jackknife(data, p = 1L, ...)

# S3 method for grouped_df
jackknife(data, p = 1L, ...)

Arguments

data
A data frame or vector
p
The number of elements to delete. p = 1 is the ordinary (delete-one) jackknife. p > 1 is the block (delete-\(p\)) jackknife.
...
Arguments passed to methods

Value

A data frame with n rows, for p = 1, or more generally, \({n}\choose{p}\) rows, and the following columns:

train
A list of resample objects. Training sets.
test
A list of resample objects. Test sets.
.id
An integer vector of identifiers

Methods (by class)

  • data.frame: Delete rows from a data frame.

  • grouped_df: Delete groups from a grouped data frame.

References

  • Davison, A. C. & Hinkley, D. V. (1997) Bootstrap Methods and Their Applications. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge. ISBN 0-521-57391-2
  • Tukey, J. W. (1958). "Bias and confidence in not quite large samples". The Annals of Mathematical Statistics. https://dx.doi.org/10.1214/aoms/1177706647.
  • Efron, B.; Stein, C. (May 1981). "The Jackknife Estimate of Variance". The Annals of Statistics. https://dx.doi.org/10.1214/aos/1176345462.
